description: As much as I love long fantasy series and adore the trilogies that seem to be the backbone of the fantasy writing world, sometimes I can’t commit to a multibook adventure. Whether it’s a quick but impactful novella or a full-length standalone novel, there is something intensely satisfying in knowing that you are reading a contained singular tale. I’m trying to use standalone fiction more to break up my jumps from series to series, and it seems to be working quite well. I’ve been working through the GdM Top 10 List of Standalone fantasy novels and adding others to my TBR list as I go. One name that kept coming up as a recommendation was Hugo Award winning Alix E. Harrow. Team GdM praises her highly, with magazine editor Beth saying, ‘Harrow can do no wrong.’ Harrow’s Southern Gothic Starling House tempted me as my first venture into her writing, I’ve had a copy of her The Once and Future Witches on my shelf for a while, so I picked th
title: REVIEW: The Once and Future Witches by Alix E. Harrow
